author: By Julie Turkewitz and José María León Cabrera
title: Ecuador, Reeling From a Candidate’s Assassination, Is Forever Changed
description: The killing of Fernando Villavicencio marks a grim turning point for a once-tranquil country now awash in violence fueled by drug gangs.
content: The 12 shots fired on Wednesday evening, killing an Ecuadorean presidential candidate as he exited a campaign event, marked a dramatic turning point for a nation that a few years ago seemed an island of security in a violent region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kolomatsky
title: What’s the Best State to Retire In? (Hint: It’s Not Florida.)
description: A new study ranked all 50 U.S. states across five categories to find which are most conducive to the retirement life.
content: If you’re approaching retirement, there are important real estate decisions to make. Living on a fixed income often influences a move, but that’s not the only thing to consider.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘The Pod Generation’ Review: Motherhood, Optimized
description: This satire on our techno-capitalist future is best enjoyed the way it’s made — without taking itself too seriously.
content: Here’s a new start-up idea: an advanced technology that allows fetuses to listen to podcasts lest they get bored in utero. That’s what the Womb Center offers in Sophie Barthes’s “The Pod Generation,” a wickedly funny and fun, if disconcerting, film that arrives right on time for our age of ChatGPT and artificial intelligence doomerism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valeria Herklotz and Marcus Cuffie
title: Dramatic Layers Push the Boundaries of Minimalism
description: This fall, turn up the volume with billowing cuts and contrasting textures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: Is Japan the Best Team Left in the World Cup?
description: Champions in 2011, the team returned to the final in the next tournament and then fell behind the world’s best teams. It’s back, and playing like a champion.
content: After the United States and seven European teams reached the quarterfinals of the Women’s World Cup four years ago, it was widely assumed that soccer’s global power base would remain stalled like a weather front in those regions four years later.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Biden Declares Disaster for Maui
description: Plus, the U.S. reached a deal with Iran to free Americans. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: President Biden issued a major disaster declaration for Maui as evacuation centers filled and tourists fled from the island in the wake of a fast-moving wildfire. The death toll climbed to 36, and hundreds of buildings were damaged in the tourist town of Lahaina and elsewhere on the western coast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By José María León Cabrera, Julie Turkewitz and Genevieve Glatsky
title: 6 Colombians Arrested in Assassination of Presidential Candidate in Ecuador
description: The candidate, Fernando Villavicencio, had been vocal about ties between the state and organized crime, in a country roiled by violence tied to drug trafficking.
content: The six suspects arrested in connection with the assassination of a presidential candidate in Ecuador are Colombian nationals, Ecuador’s interior minister, Juan Zapata, said Thursday, marking another twist in a killing that has rocked a nation consumed by violence fueled by drug trafficking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Trump and Longtime Aide Plead Not Guilty to New Charges in Documents Case
description: The former president did not appear in person for a second arraignment in the case after an updated indictment last month, and he indicated last week that he would plead not guilty.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump and a longtime aide, Walt Nauta, pleaded not guilty on Thursday to additional criminal charges in the case accusing Mr. Trump of illegally holding on to secret national security documents after leaving office and conspiring to obstruct the government’s efforts to retrieve them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Satellite Images Show the Scale of Destruction on Maui.
description: Comparing images taken before and after the fire shows extensive damage to the historic town of Lahaina.
content: Satellite images showed the extent to which wildfires, fueled by strong winds, devastated Maui’s historic district of Lahaina in several hours on Wednesday. Across the island, hundreds of buildings, including a school, a church, businesses and homes, were damaged. Recovery is expected to take years, authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson
title: After Synagogue Trial, Man With Antisemitic History Charged With Witness Tampering, Obstruction
description: On his website, Hardy Carroll Lloyd urged people to follow the example of the man who killed 11 worshipers at a Pittsburgh synagogue in 2018.
content: As jurors spent the summer in a Pittsburgh courthouse listening to weeks of testimony about the massacre that left 11 dead in a neighborhood synagogue, Hardy Carroll Lloyd was busy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: ‘King Coal’ Review: Heavy Is the Crown
description: A coal miner’s daughter turned filmmaker profiles a region’s relationship with fossil fuel and presents a eulogy for a way of life.
content: In her personal documentary “King Coal,” the director Elaine McMillion Sheldon records the modern traditions — beauty pageants, local football games and modest festivals — that commemorate the once dominant natural resource that powered central Appalachia. Through archival footage and vivid narration, Sheldon notes how the discovery of the precious black rock led to an economic boom that inspired a vibrant middle class in the 20th century, born from labor struggle. She also observes how the poisonous fossil fuel destroys the environment. The film is both a cumulative eulogy for a way of life and an examination of the climate crisis through witnessing the charred remains of these rural landscapes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Unsafe Roads: The Perils of Riding E-Bikes
description: Readers discuss ways to address the rising number of collisions with cars. Also: Indictments and Trump’s popularity; the Audubon Society; Ron DeSantis.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: What We Know About the Wildfires in Hawaii
description: The fire has been contained, but access to the islands is limited, and as the focus turns to search efforts, the death toll could rise.
content: A summer of ferocious weather across much of the United States reached the country’s most remote state on Wednesday, 2,500 miles off the West Coast, in Hawaii.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Why Many New York City Children Can’t Read
description: New York was tied for 32nd in the nation on a national assessment of students’ reading performance.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll look at why New York is lagging as states face up to a reading crisis in schools. We’ll also get details about the staggering dollar figure behind Mayor Eric Adams’s latest plea for federal help for the migrant influx.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Between Two Worlds’ Review: Juliette Binoche Goes Undercover
description: In this social-justice drama, the French actress plays an investigative journalist who poses as a cleaner to expose worker exploitation.
content: In “Between Two Worlds,” Juliette Binoche plays Marianne Winckler, a woman struggling to make ends meet in the Normandy region of France. When she arrives at an unemployment center at the start of the film, she’s sheepish and bewildered, selling herself as a “team player” to secure a minimum wage gig.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: Physicists Move One Step Closer to a Theoretical Showdown
description: The deviance of a tiny particle called the muon might prove that one of the most well-tested theories in physics is incomplete.
content: On July 24, a large team of researchers convened in Liverpool to unveil a single number related to the behavior of the muon, a subatomic particle that might open a portal to a new physics of our universe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Nazaryan
title: Rewild the National Mall
description: Big Lawn is no less formidable a foe than Big Oil or Big Tobacco, which is why an audacious gesture is needed on the most prominent lawn of all.
content: I recently committed an act of sabotage at one of the most revered landmarks in the United States, a transgression against my relatively new hometown, Washington. Walking across the National Mall, I tore open a packet of wildflower seeds — sky lupine, mountain phlox, coreopsis — and scattered its contents across the grass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Red, White & Royal Blue’ Review: Keep Calm and Pine On
description: This film, about an American president’s son who falls for a British prince, starts with a giddy premise and has the derring-do to succeed.
content: Like a corgi back-flipping over a bathtub of champagne, “Red, White & Royal Blue” starts with a giddy premise and has the derring-do to succeed. The setup is thus: Alex (Taylor Zakhar Perez), the wild child of the White House, is commanded to clean up an international PR disaster by befriending Prince Henry (Nicholas Galitzine), the cloistered British spare. In the film’s first half, the scions secretly fall in love; in the second, they fret that going public might cause another global kerfuffle just as Alex’s mother (a Southern-drawling Uma Thurman) campaigns for re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Rust’ Armorer Pleads Not Guilty as Trial Is Set for December
description: Hannah Gutierrez-Reed was responsible for weapons on the set of the western, whose cinematographer was shot and killed. She faces involuntary manslaughter charges.
content: The armorer who loaded the gun that discharged on the set of the film “Rust” in New Mexico, killing its cinematographer, is set to stand trial on involuntary manslaughter and evidence tampering charges starting Dec. 6.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘All Up in the Biz’ Review: A Documentary That’s Got What You Need
description: Biz Markie created hits like “Just a Friend” and influenced a wide range of rappers, many of whom remember him fondly in this Showtime documentary.
content: Biz Markie’s death in 2021, at the way-too-young age of 57, robbed hip-hop — hell, robbed American music, period — of one of its most idiosyncratic and singular talents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman and Elizabeth Paton
title: Coach Owner to Buy Parent of Versace and Michael Kors in Luxury Merger
description: The two fashion conglomerates, Tapestry and Capri Holdings, generate about $12 billion in combined revenue.
content: Tapestry, the fashion company that owns Coach and Kate Spade, said on Thursday that it had acquired Capri Holdings, the parent of Versace and Michael Kors, for about $8.5 billion in cash, as consolidation in the luxury market gathers pace.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

title: Phillies Starter Goes the Distance in 124-Pitch No-Hitter
description: Michael Lorenzen dominated Washington in his second start for Philadelphia after being acquired at the trading deadline.
content: The Philadelphia Phillies acquired Michael Lorenzen at the trading deadline in hopes of bolstering their starting rotation as they made a playoff push.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacey Fortin
title: Lahaina’s Historic Banyan Tree Is Scarred, but Standing
description: Planted in 1873, the tree has grown to cover more than half an acre. County officials said it “looks burned” after the Maui fires, but the roots may still be healthy.
content: Amid the charred ruins of Lahaina, one of the historic town’s cherished landmarks is still standing: a 150-year-old banyan tree. But it appears to have been badly singed by the fires that devastated Lahaina, on the west coast of Maui, and it is unclear whether the tree will survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang and Anton Troianovski
title: Nearly 50 Years After Its Last Journey, Russia Launches Toward the Moon
description: The Luna-25 mission, years in the making, will try to put a robotic lander near the moon’s south pole.
content: For the first time in nearly half a century, Russia has launched a spacecraft that is headed to the moon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Dozens of Children Die Every Year in Hot Cars. Could Technology Save Them?
description: A moment of forgetfulness by a distracted or sleep-deprived parent can be devastating. Experts and child-safety advocates have called for interior motion sensors in all vehicles.
content: Ever since Tyler Cestia left his son Thomas in his truck on a hot morning in June two years ago, he has felt, he said, like a cork bobbing in the ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Is Albariño the Next Great White Wine? It Depends.
description: For so long it’s been regarded as a simple, fruity wine to drink young and forget. But some producers in Rías Baixas are finding great potential.
content: Here in Rías Baixas, the Galician home of albariño in northwestern Spain, the most typical answer to a direct question is, “It depends.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Here’s How to Help Victims of the Hawaii Wildfires
description: Volunteers and aid groups have mobilized to help those who have been affected by the disaster. Here is some guidance on how to donate.
content: The devastating wildfires on the Hawaiian island of Maui this week have upended communities and forced thousands of residents to evacuate.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Taylor Swift Announces Fourth Album Rerecording During Eras Tour
description: Swift announced the October release of “1989 (Taylor’s Version)” during a concert in California on Wednesday.
content: It’s Taylor Swift’s summer. We’re all just living in it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Amid Sextortion’s Rise, Computer Scientists Tap A.I. to Identify Risky Apps
description: Researchers who found that a fifth of social networking apps have received multiple user complaints about sexual exploitation have launched a website to help parents vet apps.
content: Almost weekly, Brian Levine, a computer scientist at the University of Massachusetts Amherst, is asked the same question by his 14-year-old daughter: Can I download this app?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: West African Leaders Activate ‘Standby Force’ to Respond to Niger Coup
description: The military junta told an American diplomat this week that they would kill Niger’s elected president, who they’re holding hostage, if other countries tried to intervene.
content: West African leaders on Thursday said they had ordered the immediate deployment of a “standby force” ready to intervene against a coup in Niger, amid reports that coup leaders told a U.S. diplomat this week that they would kill the elected president in response to any such intervention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Judge Strikes Down F.D.A. Rule Regulating Premium Cigars
description: Hand-rolled, specialty cigars should not be subject to the broader F.D.A. regulatory rules over tobacco use, a federal judge ruled.
content: A federal judge struck down the Food and Drug Administration’s authority to regulate premium, hand-rolled cigars on Wednesday, offering relief to makers of a luxury product glamorized in films and celebrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: Special Counsel Proposes January Date for Trump’s Election Interference Trial
description: The former president’s legal team will get to suggest its own timetable for the case next week and will surely object to the government’s proposal.
content: The prosecutors overseeing the indictment of former President Donald J. Trump on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election asked a judge on Thursday to set a trial date in the case for early January, laying out an aggressive schedule for the proceeding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jourdain Searles
title: ‘Love in Taipei’ Review: A Breezy Coming-of-Age Story
description: In this romantic comedy set in Taiwan, a young American finds herself torn between a parent-approved boy wonder and a rebellious slacker.
content: Big on high jinks and light on story, “Love in Taipei” is a breezy film about a woman exploring her roots, making friends and falling in love. The romantic comedy, based on the best-selling young adult novel “Loveboat, Taipei” by Abigail Hing Wen and directed by Arvin Chen, is a charming but ultimately formulaic exploration of cultural identity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Lisa Lerer
title: Racing to Stop Trump, Republicans Descend on the Iowa State Fair
description: As the state fair and its Republican pageantry begin, Donald Trump’s rivals face a transformed political environment in Iowa, where he holds a comfortable edge in polls despite rarely visiting.
content: Over decades of presidential campaigns, the Iowa way has been to hop from town to town, taking questions from all comers and genuflecting to the local culinary traditions. Going everywhere and meeting everyone has been the gospel of how to win over voters in the low-turnout midwinter caucuses that kick off the American presidential cycle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: The historic town of Lahaina, and its legacy, is in ashes.
description: The town was once Hawaii’s royal capital, and there were fears that some of its oldest buildings had been destroyed by the wildfires.
content: For many visitors, the town of Lahaina is a place to go for tropical beaches. But for residents of Hawaii, it is a trove of history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Luke Broadwater
title: Biden Seeks $24 Billion More for Ukraine in Test of Bipartisan Support
description: The aid request is the first by the president since Republicans took over the House, and some party leaders have expressed opposition to spending more to help Ukraine beat back Russian forces.
content: President Biden appealed to Congress on Thursday for an additional $24 billion to help Ukraine defeat Russia’s invasion, setting up a major test of whether the expansive war effort retains the bipartisan support it has enjoyed since Moscow sent troops across the border nearly 18 months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones and Rick Rojas
title: Warm Waters Complicate Hurricane Forecasts and Raise Fears Along the Coast
description: Officials on Thursday increased the number of storms they expect this season, another troubling sign for coastal communities that have been unnerved by extremely warm waters.
content: In places still scarred by the devastation of recent storms, the arrival of hurricane season stirs anxiety and apprehension that push many to search for any sign — some based more on superstition than science — that can provide even a wisp of clarity about what may be headed their way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: Woman Lied to Buy Firearms for Son Who Later Threatened Politicians, U.S. Says
description: Prosecutors say that Michelle Berka of Michigan lied when purchasing firearms last year. Her son was arrested in March with some of the same weapons after threatening online to kill President Biden, court records show.
content: A Michigan woman has been charged with lying to buy firearms that were found in March with her 30-year-old son, who was arrested that month after making death threats online against President Biden and Gov. Gretchen Whitmer, federal agents and prosecutors said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
title: A Drone’s View Behind Russian Lines: Cratered Fields and Charred Armor
description: A Ukrainian unit sent a drone into Russian-occupied territory to surveil the battlefront, and it brought back vivid images of the Russian side of the war zone.
content: The images a reconnaissance drone sent back to Ukrainian forces provided a vivid portrait of the Russian side of the war zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Minnesota’s Democratic Governor ‘Endorses’ at the Iowa State Fair. He’s for the Pork Chop.
description: Gov. Tim Walz toured the fairgrounds, surrounded by Republican presidential hopefuls, touting President Biden and his party’s policies.
content: If anyone asks, Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota has an endorsement in the Republican presidential contest — his Red River neighbor, Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Picks Up, but Details Under the Surface Are Encouraging
description: Economists looked past the first acceleration in overall inflation in more than a year and saw signs that price pressures continued to moderate in July.
content: Fresh inflation data offered the latest evidence that price increases were meaningfully cooling, good news for consumers and policymakers alike more than a year into the Federal Reserve’s campaign to slow the economy and wrestle cost increases back under control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Artem Chekh
title: I Spent Five Days in a Trench Waiting for Death. It Was Pure Hell.
description: Did I really want to fight?
content: When Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine, I was writing a novel. It took place in America in 1863, and followed a Ukrainian man as he traveled from Virginia to Missouri, meeting on his way various weirdos, soldiers, deserters and runaway slaves. I’ve always been very interested in the history of the United States, and the idea of ​​integrating a Ukrainian protagonist — not a classic emigrant but a soldier on the side of the North, with his own history of servitude under the yoke of the Russian Empire — into the realities of the Civil War was attractive to me.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Unusual weather conditions are driving Maui’s wildfires.
description: Atypical weather conditions conspiring with a healthy dose of bad luck created ideal circumstances for wildfires to ignite.
content: Atypical weather conditions conspiring with a healthy dose of bad luck created ideal circumstances on Tuesday for wildfires to ignite on Maui and then spread, ravaging the island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Why the Iowa State Fair Matters
description: Presidential hopefuls — favorites and long shots alike — gather at the event every four years to meet voters and kingmakers in advance of the first nominating contest.
content: The Iowa State Fair is one of the most famous stops in a presidential campaign, known for delivering the kind of memorable moments that can define a candidacy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Tannenbaum
title: How ‘The Last Waltz’ Became One of Rock’s Greatest Docs
description: The film capturing the Band’s final performance in 1976 is a showcase for the group’s main songwriter and guitarist, Robbie Robertson. And for some, that was a problem.
content: By the mid-1970s, the Band was well known as the group that had backed Bob Dylan on his first electric tour and released a series of its own reverentially reviewed albums that returned music to a pre-psychedelic era and augured a return-to-basics movement in rock. But in 1976, with the quality and sales of its albums both declining, the Band announced a farewell show, full of illustrious guest stars, at the Winterland Ballroom in San Francisco on Thanksgiving Day. The gala concert would be filmed by Martin Scorsese, who in the last few years had directed the provocative and acclaimed films “Mean Streets,” “Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore” and “Taxi Driver.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Pitches Manufacturing Boom on Southwest Tour
description: During a stop in New Mexico, the president highlighted how one of his signature pieces of legislation will benefit blue-collar workers.
content: President Biden on Wednesday entered a wind tower manufacturing plant surrounded by desert boasting of declining unemployment, waning inflation and a manufacturing boom — all metrics that should make his three-state Southwest tour a victory lap.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anjali Huynh and Reid J. Epstein
title: Pence Avoids Trump’s Name as He Fields a Jan. 6 Question
description: The former vice president refers to his “former running mate” and to the “former president,” but he declined to refer to the Republican front-runner by name.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence never said Donald J. Trump’s name.  In 21 minutes on the Iowa State Fair soapbox on Thursday, Mr. Pence referred to Mr. Trump as “my former running mate” and “the former president” but made no reference to anything that happened during what he usually calls “the Trump-Pence administration.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel’s Supreme Court Prepares to Rule on Its Own Fate
description: The justices will be scrutinized as never before at a hearing in September on the first part of a judicial overhaul that the government pushed through Parliament, angering many Israelis.
content: For the first time in Israel’s history, all 15 of its Supreme Court justices will crowd onto the bench on Sept. 12 to hear a case together. The reason: This one is so momentous that it could not only decide the powers of the court itself but also kindle a constitutional crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: In the Art of Tuan Andrew Nguyen, Vietnam’s Nightmares Live On
description: The artist’s video installations and sculptures show how the Vietnam War still reverberates through generations.
content: One of the wisest, most beautiful and unsettling exhibitions in New York this summer is “Tuan Andrew Nguyen: Radiant Remembrance” at the New Museum, a show about coming to terms with the intergenerational trauma of war. Nguyen works in video and also makes art objects pertaining to them. In the three recent moving-image installations here he creates narratives that operate in cinematic and real space in different, often affecting ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: The Dog Walker With the Chuck Close Painting Finally Has His Day
description: Just when it looked as if Mark Herman’s painting was unsellable, his luck turned around. Now, who’s going to play him in the movie?
content: The way Mark Herman imagines it, Jack Black should play him in the movie: the scruffy dog walker whose dying client gave him a long-lost Chuck Close painting, and who then went through serial misadventures trying to sell it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Thomas Fuller
title: Death Toll Soars in Maui, as Rescue Crews Scour Decimated Town
description: Lahaina lay in ruins following a wildfire that the governor said most likely killed more than 60 people, making it the deadliest in Hawaii’s history.
content: The death toll in a historic Maui town leveled by a wildfire soared to 53 on Thursday as the U.S. military joined search and rescue operations in the charred ruins of one of Hawaii’s most celebrated tourist destinations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Inside California’s Program to Better Treat Addiction in Prisons
description: A conversation with Noah Weiland, who dug into the state’s sprawling drug addiction program.
content: The statistics on drug addiction in American prisons are stark.

title: Jury Acquits Michigan Trooper Who Used Dog to Subdue a Man
description: The man, who was bitten several times, could be heard in dashboard camera footage pleading with Trooper Parker Surbrook to pull the dog off him.
content: A state trooper in Michigan has been acquitted by a jury after being charged with felonious assault for using a police dog to subdue an unarmed, injured man in 2020, prosecutors said.

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Who Was Fernando Villavicencio?
description: The presidential candidate who was assassinated on Wednesday had a long history in Ecuador’s public affairs, largely as an antagonist to those in power.
content: Union leader. Muckraking journalist. Legislator. Presidential candidate. And, now, assassin’s victim.

author: By Sarah Lyon
title: Love Me, Love My Dog
description: A wedding is incomplete for some couples without their canine companions — whether on the dance floor, down the aisle or in the dressing room.
content: On July 9, 2022, Johnny Hilbrant-Partridge and Justin Partridge presented each other with gifts ahead of their wedding ceremony at French’s Point, a private coastal estate in Stockton Springs, Maine. Standing before friends and family, Mr. Partridge first unwrapped a Movado watch from Mr. Hilbrant-Partridge. source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tanya Sichynsky
title: Return of the Recipe Matchmaker
description: What to bring to a book club potluck, what side dish to make to please a crowd at a child’s birthday party and what to do with all those cherry tomatoes.
content: Sound the Recipe Matchmaker alarm, because we are so back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Robbie Robertson’s 16 Essential Songs
description: The Band’s arrangements evoked bygone eras but weren’t limited by them. Hear some of the best tracks led by the songwriter and guitarist, who died this week at 80, alongside standout solo material.
content: In Robbie Robertson’s music, earthiness and mystery were never far apart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Herbert J. Siegel, Investor in Major Media Deals, Dies at 95
description: As head of Chris-Craft Industries, he played a role in the Time-Warner merger and sold 10 television stations to Rupert Murdoch.
content: Herbert J. Siegel, a maverick investor who became a billionaire entertainment-industry mogul most notable for finally enabling the merger of Warner Communications and Time Inc. in 1989 and for selling 10 television stations to Rupert Murdoch’s News Corporation in 2000, died on Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Getting a Taxi in Italy Is Too Hard. Fixing That Is Not Easy.
description: The government took steps this week to increase the supply of cabs after months of shortages, but critics say the problems with the industry run deeper.
content: This summer, countless tourists, as well as residents of many top Italian destinations, found themselves in the fruitless pursuit of elusive game: a taxi.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Trachta
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Season 2 Episode 9 Recap: Budding Expectations
description: Lisa has big news. So does Carrie. OK, so do a bunch of characters.
content: The first time Carrie started dating Aidan, back in Season 3 of “Sex and the City,” she found herself routinely waking up with a gasp in the middle of the night. Something felt off. Something felt wrong. But after scouring for whatever unchecked item on her to-do list was giving her this anxiety, she found that, in fact, she “hadn’t so much as missed a teeth cleaning.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: The New Look in Cocktails? Layers and Stripes.
description: Drinks with colorful bands of liquors that float to the top or sink to the bottom are grabbing attention at bars all over.
content: Bartenders call it “the fajita effect.” As an eye-catching cocktail sails on a tray through a room, it inspires several more orders of the same drink. Fajita favorites of recent years have included the espresso martini, all manner of blue cocktails and any drink on fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle, Ross Douthat and Carlos Lozada
title: How to Beat Trump in a World Where Indictments Actually Help Him
description: Does Ron DeSantis stand a chance? Does Joe Biden?
content: Donald Trump was impeached twice. He has been indicted three times. He lost the 2020 election. And yet he’s the clear Republican front-runner for 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Diana Nguyen, Carlos Prieto, Summer Thomad, Nina Feldman, Sydney Harper, Devon Taylor, Paige Cowett, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Alyssa Moxley
title: Lives, Livelihoods, and the High Cost of Heat
description: What are the physical and economic consequences of higher temperatures?
content: This summer, unrelenting heat waves have taken a devastating toll in many parts of the world, putting this year on track to be the hottest ever recorded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Medusa Deluxe’ Review: Curl Up and Die
description: A gruesome attack on a stylist upends a hairdressing contest in this invigoratingly bold debut.
content: Suffused with the sting of hair spray and the scent of Herbal Essences, “Medusa Deluxe” swaggers onto our screens, all cigarette smoke and mirrors. From its playfully inventive opening to its flash-forward finale, Thomas Hardiman’s wild — and wildly impressive — first feature, set during a British regional hairdressing competition, is a proudly indelicate, painstakingly structured pleasure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Florida Schools Try to Adapt to New Rules on Gender, Bathrooms and Pronouns
description: As schools start, it’s been more paperwork, a culling of reading lists, as well as new regulations about bathrooms.
content: As a new school year begins in Florida this week, parents are filling out a flurry of new forms — specifying a student’s nickname or new name; allowing a child to check certain books out of the library; and opting in or out of health services ranging from counseling to temperature checks, calamine lotion and ice packs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Manuela Andreoni
title: How Climate Change Turned Lush Hawaii Into a Tinderbox
description: Declining rainfall, rising temperatures and invasive species have left the islands more susceptible to wildfires.
content: The fires in Hawaii would be shocking anywhere — killing at least 36 people, in one of the deadliest wildfires in the United States in modern history. But the devastation is especially striking because of where it happened: In a state defined by its lush vegetation, a far cry from the dry landscape normally associated with fire threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and John Koblin
title: Striking Writers and Studios Agree to Restart Negotiations
description: The two sides in the Hollywood stalemate will formally meet on Friday, after an informal sidebar session last week.
content: As television and movie writers started their 101st day on strike on Thursday, the leaders of their union said they had agreed to formally restart negotiations with studios for a new three-year contract.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Heat Singes the Mind, Not Just the Body
description: Hot weather can destabilize mood, exacerbate mental health disorders and complicate drug treatment. Climate change itself is a stressor, scientists say.
content: If you find that the blistering, unrelenting heat is making you anxious and irritable, even depressed, it’s not all in your head. Soaring temperatures can damage not just the body but also the mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrea R. Flores
title: We Know What Doesn’t Work at the Border. Here’s a Better Solution.
description: Abandoning our nation’s moral commitment to protect asylum seekers is not the way forward.
content: U.S. asylum laws were designed to protect people fleeing harm. They were enacted in the decades following the Holocaust to ensure that the United States never again turned away people fleeing persecution. But now, many blame these laws for the chaos and inhumanity at the nation’s southern border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann and Amir Hamja
title: At Penn Station, Searching for Sequins and Style
description: A reporter and photographer combed train cars and platforms in search of the most fashionable Beyoncé fans.
content: In February, when Beyoncé announced that she would embark on a world tour for her “Renaissance” album, New Yorkers began furiously plotting their journeys to MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Says He Won’t Sign Loyalty Pledge Required for G.O.P. Debate
description: The Republican National Committee has demanded that 2024 contenders pledge to support the eventual nominee in order to debate. The former president is refusing.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump said on Wednesday that he was unwilling to meet one of the requirements to participate in the first Republican presidential debate, refusing to sign a pledge to support the eventual nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coralie Kraft
title: Hello? It’s ‘Telemarketers,’ Here to Tell You About an Amazing Scam
description: In a rowdy new HBO docu-series, two former telemarketers with a camcorder take on an industry they say was ripping people off in the name of charity.
content: Before caller ID, and before “Scam Likely,” answering the phone was an exercise in patience. A telltale click and tinny, faraway voice heralded the most dreaded of callers: a telemarketer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Farewell to a Store That Was Gap for Billionaires
description: Tiina the Store is closing forever. Or is it?
content: Her fashion paragon is Georgia O’Keeffe. And the shop Tiina Laakkonen ran for over a decade from a frame house on Route 27 in Amagansett, N.Y., halfway between East Hampton and Montauk, seems like the sort of place where you could imagine the legendary artist augmenting her chic if austere wardrobe — that is, if Georgia O’Keeffe had been dressed by the Row.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Senison
title: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
description: This week’s properties are in Hamilton Heights, Gramercy Park and Prospect Heights.
content: A 2,685-square-foot limestone townhouse from 1910, with a duplex that has two bedrooms on the garden level and a living room, family room and kitchen on the parlor floor; and two stacked one-bedroom apartments above. They house has gas heat, fireplaces, stained-glass windows, skylights, an unfinished basement, a garden with perennial plantings, a fish pond and a gazebo. Kenneth Thornton, Sotheby’s International Realty, 315-727-8553; sothebysrealty.com
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman
title: Patrons Want Straight Answers in Crooked House Pub’s Demise
description: The beloved tilted landmark in the West Midlands area of England was razed after a fire that police suspect was arson, leaving locals looking for answers.
content: Getting a drink in The Crooked House pub could feel intoxicating, even if you’d ordered a lemonade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Hey, America, Grow Up!
description: How an epidemic of immaturity swept our land.
content: If I were asked to trace the decline of the American psyche, I suppose I would go to a set of cultural changes that started directly after World War II and built over the next few decades, when writers as diverse as Philip Rieff, Christopher Lasch and Tom Wolfe noticed the emergence of what came to be known as the therapeutic culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and Jin Yu Young
title: Tourists Are Asked to Leave Maui as Wildfires Burn
description: Local officials have asked visitors, who drive the island’s economy, to leave while the island is in crisis mode.
content: The wildfires on Maui, which have been linked to dozens of deaths and burned much of the historic district of the town of Lahaina, may also have long-term impacts on the tourism industry that plays an outsize role in the island’s economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: In Rare Move, Russian Tech Tycoon Condemns War in Ukraine
description: Arkady Volozh is only the second sanctioned Russian businessman to take an unequivocal public position against the invasion.
content: A founder of Russia’s largest technology company condemned his country’s war in Ukraine on Thursday, a rare step among Russian tycoons caught between fear of Western sanctions and retribution at home.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: Among the books we recommend this week are two histories of social ferment that led to consequential change in different places and eras and conditions: Christopher Clark’s “Revolutionary Spring,” about the unrest that swept Europe in 1848, and Paul Kix’s “You Have to Be Prepared to Die Before You Can Begin to Live,” about the civil rights struggle that unfolded in Birmingham, Ala., in 1963. In very different ways, both books feel as if they’re in conversation with this moment; you can’t go wrong reading either, or both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Let’s Have a Face-Off on Trump’s Indictment
description: What the two sides might tell each other if they had a chance.
content: The latest Trump indictment is much more complicated than the first two Trump indictments and probably any indictment that would come out of Fulton County, Ga. It attacks a scheme that played out across several weeks, in several states, involving dozens of others, including Trump-allied activists, those cited as co-conspirators and G.O.P. hacks who tried to overturn the 2020 election in state after state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Michael D. Shear
title: U.S. Reaches Deal With Iran to Free Americans for Jailed Iranians and Funds
description: Five American detainees will eventually be allowed to leave Iran in exchange for Tehran gaining access to $6 billion for humanitarian purposes and the United States freeing several jailed Iranians.
content: The United States and Iran have reached an agreement to win the freedom of five imprisoned Americans in exchange for several jailed Iranians and eventual access to about $6 billion in Iranian oil revenue, according to several people familiar with the deal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Yes, R. Crumb Made a Yoga Mat
description: Plus: tea-infused gin, silk wear inspired by neon signs — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
content: When the Japanese brand Trunk opened its first hotel in central Shibuya in 2017, its Western-influenced rooms, with their calming neutral palettes, were a respite from one of the world’s busiest neighborhoods. At the same time, the cozy, moodily dark lobby was conceived to be a communal social space — rare for Japan, a country where lodging tends to be more cloistered — for locals and tourists to work on their laptops or drink highballs with friends. If that place was about bringing people in, Trunk’s next one, a 25-room property opening Sept. 1, is meant to draw eyes outward, particularly toward verdant Yoyogi Park, a 133-acre green space in northern Shibuya that the new concrete-clad, seven-story building faces. With balconies extending from every room and a rooftop pool club — another rarity for a Tokyo hotel — the idea is not only to bring visitors to a rising corner of the district that’s increasingly crowded with cool shops and restaurants but also to give guests a chance to relax away from the thrum while gazing out over the tree line at the metropolis beyond. The design, led by the Japanese architect Keiji Ashizawa’s firm, with interiors by the Danish company Norm, has all kinds of warm wood touches and beige textures, and the restaurant will serve pizza and Italian food: Not at all rare in Tokyo these days, but comforting nonetheless. Rooms from about $419; trunk-hotel.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Hackers Stole $6 Million From the New Haven School System
description: Justin Elicker, the mayor of New Haven, said on Thursday that $3.6 million has since been recovered.
content: Hackers stole more than $6 million from the New Haven, Conn., public school system, Justin Elicker, the city’s mayor, said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: pheromone
description: This word has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word pheromone has appeared in two articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 24 in “To Display 500,000 Ants, No Simple Ant Farm Will Do” by Emily Anthes:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson, Ana Swanson and Jeanna Smialek
title: Heat, War and Trade Protections Raise Uncertainty for Food Prices
description: Experts are warning of a new normal in which food supplies — and prices — could be rocked more regularly.
content: As the rate of food price inflation eases in the United States and Europe, analysts are warning of a new era of volatility in global food prices, ushered in by a series of threats coming together in unprecedented ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Kennedy
title: ‘Sound of the Police’ Review: The Silence and the Fury
description: This documentary dives into the nation’s outrageous history of the policing of Black citizens by touching on the 2022 killing of Amir Locke.
content: It is not the first image in “Sound of the Police,” a documentary about the chronically vexed relationship between Black people and police officers, but it is its most chilling: the ominous hush of the police at a front door, signaling the horror to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teo Bugbee
title: ‘Aurora’s Sunrise’ Review: A Patchwork Record of the Armenian Genocide
description: This standout documentary combines archival footage and animated re-enactments to share one survivor’s memories.
content: The documentary “Aurora’s Sunrise” shares the great and terrible story of Aurora Mardiganian, an Armenian survivor of the genocide that began in 1915. Aurora was 14 years old and living in a small town in the Ottoman Empire when the violence started. Her peaceful life was obliterated when her father and brother were rounded up and murdered by Ottoman Turk soldiers. Aurora was then forced into a death march across the desert of what is now Syria. She survived weeks of the march and two years of subsequent violence. Aurora witnessed unimaginable atrocities: rivers teeming with corpses, children begging for their lives, bandits pillaging the caravans of survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: On the Hudson, Visions for a New Native American Art
description: A frisky group of Indigenous performers, videomakers and sculptors have a presence in the art world they haven’t had before.
content: A MAGA-style baseball cap, scarlet and sloganeering, sits on a shelf, as if for sale, surrounded by other promotional retail: T-shirts, totes, lighters. “Make Amerika Red Again” is embroidered on the front of the cap, which is also stitched with pretty bead work and topped by a yellow feather.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘The Eternal Memory’ Review: A Love That Lasts When Recollections Fade
description: This documentary from Maite Alberdi looks at how a couple faces one partner’s Alzheimer’s diagnosis.
content: The word “Alzheimer’s” isn’t spoken until well into “The Eternal Memory.” While that may be because this documentary’s subjects rarely mention it themselves, withholding the diagnosis also seems like a deliberate choice by the director, Maite Alberdi (“The Mole Agent”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Kuwait and Lebanon Look to Ban ‘Barbie’ for Moral Reasons
description: The Middle Eastern governments said the movie, which does not overtly portray same-sex relationships, violated their conservative beliefs and principles.
content: Although the “Barbie” movie is a billion-dollar global hit, officials in Lebanon and Kuwait moved on Wednesday to ban the film, saying its content contradicts the conservative values of their countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: ‘And Just Like That …’ Episode 9 Fashion: Dressing for the Apartment You Want
description: In the new episode, Carrie shops for real estate, and Lisa Todd Wexley makes an announcement.
content: This article contains spoilers for Episode 9 of the second season of “And Just Like That …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Morning Briefing: A Major Disaster in Hawaii
description: Also, Japan at the World Cup.
content: As the death toll from wildfires on the Hawaiian island of Maui climbed to 36, President Biden issued a major disaster declaration. Evacuation centers filled,  tourists fled and rescuers searched for survivors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: Epstein Victim May Pursue Claims Against Two Wall St. Executives
description: A “carve out” provision allows at least one sexual abuse victim of Jeffrey Epstein who settled with his estate to pursue claims against Leon Black and James Staley. Other victims may follow.
content: At least one longtime sexual abuse victim of Jeffrey Epstein who received a monetary settlement from his estate can also pursue separate claims against two powerful former Wall Street executives who had ties to the convicted sex offender, according to two people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ismay
title: Russia Is Replicating Iranian Drones and Using Them to Attack Ukraine
description: Called the Geran-2, the drones are a Russian-made version of the Shahed-136, which explodes on impact, researchers say.
content: Russia has begun making copies of attack drones it acquired from Iran last year and is using them in combat against Ukrainian forces despite sanctions imposed to cripple the country’s weapons production, according to a report issued Thursday by a weapons research group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Trumpets Legislation for Veterans Despite Backlog in Claims
description: More than half of the roughly 843,000 claims submitted since the legislation was signed have been processed. But there are still more than 384,700 applications pending.
content: Kerrie Wiener did not know if she had another fight in her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Conservative Case Emerges to Disqualify Trump for Role on Jan. 6
description: Two law professors active in the Federalist Society wrote that the original meaning of the 14th Amendment makes Donald Trump ineligible to hold government office.
content: Two prominent conservative law professors have concluded that Donald J. Trump is ineligible to be president under a provision of the Constitution that bars people who have engaged in an insurrection from holding government office. The professors are active members of the Federalist Society, the conservative legal group, and proponents of originalism, the method of interpretation that seeks to determine the Constitution’s original meaning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: Hip-hop at 50
description: An essential American art form reaches a milestone.
content: For 50 years, the essential writing — fables, comedies, diaries; adventure, memoir, porn — about young Black life in this country has been happening in hip-hop. Songs about feelings, fantasies, dilemmas, confessions, fantasias. What else is Notorious B.I.G.’s “Ready to Die” and its grueling, knowing, melodic re-creation of moral decay and sexual congress other than a triumph of literature? It is but one title on a shelf buckling with scores of comparable powerhouses. That’s one masterpiece set in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Typhoon Khanun Turns Deadly in South Korea
description: After pummeling southern Japan again, the storm moved slowly up the Korean Peninsula, bringing torrential rain and winds. One person died in floodwaters.
content: As Typhoon Khanun continued to pummel South Korea, the floods it has caused left one person dead and cut off power to 40,000 households on Thursday, adding to the toll of an abnormally wet and deadly storm season in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: It’s Not Reagan’s Party Anymore
description: Ronald Reagan’s “three-legged stool” coalition supported the G.O.P. for decades. Our latest poll leaves little doubt that Donald J. Trump has put an end to that era.
content: For more than 30 years, the Republican Party was defined by Ronald Reagan’s famous three-legged stool: a coalition of fiscal conservatives, social conservatives and national security hawks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Love Life’ Review: Encounters in Grief
description: In this Japanese drama from Koji Fukada, the death of a child alters life for a couple and for the boy’s previously absent father.
content: The Japanese writer-director Koji Fukada made his international mark with “Harmonium” (2017). Like that film, “Love Life,” his latest feature, concerns a family shaken up both by an interloper’s arrival and by a sudden tragedy, this time in the reverse order.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos and Dana Rubinstein
title: New York’s Attorney General Breaks With Gov. Hochul Over Migrant Crisis
description: Letitia James, the state attorney general, has declined to represent Gov. Kathy Hochul in a court proceeding over how to care for thousands of asylum seekers.
content: Divisions among New York Democrats widened on Thursday around the influx of migrants arriving from the southern border, as the state attorney general took the unusual step of declining to represent Gov. Kathy Hochul in legal proceedings over how to care for thousands of newcomers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abby Ellin
title: But How Will They Get the Bags Home From Camp?
description: Camp Trucking, a delivery service for campers’ bags, shut down abruptly, leaving families with few options and causing general havoc.
content: Paige Axel was working when an unwelcome email arrived. It was from Tyler Hill Camp, where her 14-year-old son, Sawyer, has been a camper for the last seven years. The news was grim: Camp Trucking, the transportation company that had shepherded two duffel bags’ worth of Sawyer’s belongings to camp and back again, had closed its doors less than two weeks before camp was set to end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: How Old Is That Polar Bear? The Answer Is in Its Blood.
description: So-called “epigenetic clocks” are helping wildlife biologists estimate the ages of animals far more easily than in the past.
content: Susannah Woodruff can’t wait to stop pulling teeth out of polar bears.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josephine Sittenfeld
title: I Wanted to Capture the Fleeting Magic of a Summer at Camp in Photographs
description: This is what a perfect day at Camp Killooleet looks like.
content: In 1999, after my freshman year in college, I was a counselor at a camp in central Vermont. It changed my life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Ephrat Livni
title: Bob Iger Tweaks Disney’s Strategy on Streaming
description: The C.E.O. of the media giant has shifted focus to making more money from subscribers after losing billions in a bid to build scale.
content: Even if Bob Iger, Disney’s C.E.O., didn’t have much to reveal about big-ticket M.&A. on Wednesday — other than continuing to suggest he may sell its legacy TV businesses — he did make news with the company’s quarterly earnings report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Wired Names Katie Drummond as Its Next Leader
description: Ms. Drummond joins the tech publication from Vice Media, where she was a senior executive.
content: Katie Drummond will be the next top editor of Wired, overseeing the tech publication’s teams around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Even as Golf Evolves, Trump Remains on the Outs
description: LIV Golf has embraced the former president. But much of golf’s establishment is keeping its distance, even as LIV and the PGA Tour seek a détente.
content: Walking toward a tee box in Virginia in May, former President Donald J. Trump offered an awfully accurate assessment of the way many golf executives viewed him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amor Towles
title: The Corpse in the Library
description: Once at the center of the murder mystery, the cadaver has become increasingly incidental to the action and now figures as little more than a prop.
content: For over 100 years the cadaver, that unsung hero of murder mysteries, has been accommodating, gracious and generally on time. There is no other figure in crime who has proved more reliable. Since the murder mystery first gained popularity, there have been two world wars, multiple economic crises, dance crazes and moonshots, the advent of radio, cinema, television and the internet. Ideas of right and wrong have evolved, tastes have changed. But through it all, the cadaver has shown up without complaint to do its job. A clock-puncher of the highest order, if you will.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: White Sharks May Have ‘Buddies,’ Researchers Say
description: Scientists have discovered two white sharks that appear to be travel companions, swimming over 4,000 miles together since they were fitted with satellite tags in December.
content: In the minds of many, the fearsome white shark is a loner. It cares only about food, not its own kind. But new research indicates that some of the creatures may actually have friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
description: The men in kilts are back, as is a beloved British character played by Matt Berry.
content: ‘Men in Kilts: A Roadtrip With Sam and Graham’When to watch: Friday at 9:30 p.m., on Starz.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: How Long Will Companies Keep Raising Prices on Consumer Goods?
description: As companies reported their latest quarterly earnings, their executives were frequently asked about their next moves on pricing.
content: Companies that sell food and other household staples — many of which have reported increased profits in their latest quarterly earnings — are weighing their next moves on prices as inflation cools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! JetBlue Stranded Our Boy Scout Troop in New York City
description: When their flight from Denver to J.F.K. was delayed, six scouts and three adults missed their connection back to Savannah, Ga., and had to make a choice: Wait five days or find their own way home.
content: I was one of three adults who led a backpacking trip to the Colorado Rockies this past June with six teenage Boy Scouts from Troop 876 of Savannah, Ga. After seven nights camping, our eighth night — June 26 — was to be aboard a redeye to Kennedy Airport, followed by a morning flight to Savannah, both on JetBlue Airways. But our Denver departure was delayed over two hours and we missed the connection. We waited for three hours in line, only to politely be told the next flight available was five days later, even after we offered to fly to Atlanta, Charleston, S.C., or Jacksonville, Fla., instead. JetBlue would not provide a hotel. So we opted for a refund (plus $12 meal vouchers), rented two cars and drove 14 hours home, racking up about $1,200 in travel expenses. But when our refunds from JetBlue came through, they totaled $261 for nine of us, only 18 percent of the original cost. A customer service representative later explained to me by phone that we had been reimbursed for only the New York to Savannah leg. We believe JetBlue should have gotten us on an earlier flight on a different airline or at least reimbursed us for the nine fares and fees totaling $1,458, and perhaps chipped in for the expenses to get home. Can you help? Spencer, Savannah, Ga.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Houman Barekat
title: ‘Food’ Review: It’s an Acquired Taste
description: At the Edinburgh Festival, Geoff Sobelle presents a dinner party as a theatrical spectacle, in which silliness is the end in itself.
content: In an auditorium in Scotland, the American theater artist Geoff Sobelle is hosting a dinner party. The stage is taken up by an enormous square table, laid out with plates and cutlery. Around three of its sides sit twenty-four audience members. At the center of the fourth is the waistcoated figure of Sobelle, who brings wine, hands out menus and takes orders. When one lady requests a baked potato, he produces a bucket full of earth and empties it out onto the table; he plants a seed in the mound, waters it and waits a while before reaching in to pull out a large spud.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Shaffer
title: ‘Jules’ Review: Close Encounters of the Lonely Kind
description: Ben Kingsley plays an elderly man struggling with a fading memory when an extraterrestrial crashes into his life.
content: Generally speaking, alien movies tend to go one of either two ways: horror or tenderness. Marc Turtletaub’s “Jules” falls squarely in the latter category — the titular alien who crash-lands in small-town Pennsylvania is a vegetarian, and eats apple slices given to him by his genial human host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Planning Travel to Hawaii? Here’s What You Need to Know
description: The extent of the damage from the wildfires is still being assessed. Many hotel companies and airlines are offering refunds and waiving cancellation fees for Maui-bound travelers.
content: About 11,000 tourists have been evacuated and another 1,500 were slated to fly out of the Hawaiian island of Maui on Thursday, after wildfires inflamed by gusting winds killed at least 36 people, destroyed homes and businesses and caused outages to cellphone service and power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich
title: After Days of Chaos at Rikers, Judge to Hear Arguments for Takeover
description: Following years of incremental arguments and reports, Judge Laura Swain moved toward stripping control from New York City.
content: A federal judge Thursday opened the door to stripping New York City of control over Rikers Island, in a hearing that highlighted the daily chaos that reigns in the jails despite repeated assertions by Mayor Eric Adams and his allies that conditions are improving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan, Simon Romero and Shawn Hubler
title: Lahaina Showcased Centuries of Hawaiian History. Now Its Gems are Gone.
description: A city devastated by fire in Maui was a magnet for tourists. But for families from Lahaina, especially Native Hawaiians, it was a home with a deep history.
content: Situated in the heart of Lahaina, the 34-room Pioneer Inn was a piece of history built in 1901 by George Alan Freeland, a British adventurer who followed his star to Maui and started a family with a Native Hawaiian woman. The hotel became the linchpin of a modest business empire that eventually included a saloon, a liquor wholesale operation and movie houses in plantation camps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Nate Schweber
title: New York City Said It Had No More Beds for Migrants. What Changed?
description: Migrants were sleeping in the streets because there was no more space, the city said. Within days, it had found beds, and critics argued there had been room all along.
content: For several nights last week, New York City’s migrant crisis seemed to have passed a breaking point: As many as 300 newly arrived migrants were left to sleep on the sidewalk outside the main processing center in Midtown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Food Prices Ticked Up in July, but Showed Signs of Moderating
description: The cost of food rose 0.2 percent in July from the prior month, but several categories showed a slowdown in price increases.

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson and Sean Donnola
title: Martha Rosler Wants to Know Why We Still Aren’t Outraged
description: Since the 1960s, the artist has channeled her wit and her conscience into works that face American injustice head-on.
content: ON THE CRISP March afternoon of my first meeting with the artist Martha Rosler, details were emerging about the victims of the 19th school shooting in the United States in 2023. Equipped with three firearms, someone had killed six people at a Nashville elementary school, including three 9-year-old children. Walking through Chelsea to Rosler’s New York gallery, Mitchell-Innes & Nash, past a gaggle of kids’ scooters parked inside the glass-fronted foyer of a school, I wondered if continuing on with my day as if this calamity hadn’t just happened was a necessary form of self-preservation or an unforgivable failure of empathy. Among the questions I wanted to ask Rosler, who has spent the past six decades calling attention to exactly this schism in the American psyche, was how she keeps going when nothing seems to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wesley Morris
title: How Hip-Hop Conquered the World
description: We’re celebrating hip-hop’s 50th anniversary this week. Wesley Morris traces the art form from its South Bronx origins to all-encompassing triumph.
content: We’ve gathered here today to raise a glass to hip-hop. It’s 50, baby! Half a century of effrontery, dexterity, elasticity, rambunctiousness, ridiculousness, bleakness, spunk, swagger, juice, jiggle and wit, of defiant arrogance, devastating humor, consumptive lust and violent distress, of innovation, danger, doubt and drip. Salud! I’ll be honest, though. I knew the magazine covers and concerts and TV specials were coming, but I wasn’t feeling it. Seemed too arbitrary a date. Or maybe just impossible to ascertain. What I did feel was that hip-hop has so thoroughly infused the atmosphere of American life (we’ll just start with this country), that it has pushed so much forward — who cares that it’s pushing 50?
source.name: The New York Times

content: Brice Marden, whose elegant fusion of minimalism and Abstract Expressionism in the 1960s revivified painting and established him as one of the most admired and influential artists of his generation, died on Thursday at his home in Tivoli, N.Y., in Dutchess County. He was 84.

description: And how should the United States respond?
